Linguistic analysis: The expert may have analyzed the language used in the claim to determine if it aligns with the typical language used in official statements or if it contains any linguistic patterns that suggest it may be fabricated.
Historical data: The expert may have cross-referenced the claim with historical data on past presidents to verify the accuracy of the statement. This could involve examining records of past presidents and their backgrounds to determine if the claim accurately represents the proportion of governors and senators who have become presidents.
Political expertise: The expert may have relied on their knowledge and expertise in the field of politics to assess the claim. This could involve considering the political landscape and the likelihood of governors and senators becoming presidents based on historical trends and political dynamics.
Source evaluation: The expert may have evaluated the credibility and reliability of the source of the claim. This could involve assessing the reputation and expertise of the individual or organization making the claim and considering any potential biases or motivations they may have.
